occurrences.line_text: Knowing his voice although not heard long sin,
Suspect her truth: yet since no' vntruth he knew,
For since mine eye your ioyous sight did mis,
For since my brest was launcht with louely dart
And euer since hath kept in darksome caue,
But since faire Sunne hath sperst that lowring clowd,
And sight of men, since his late luckelesse fray.
Yet of his prowesse proofe he since hath made
Themselues in vaine: for since that glauncing sight,
Since I the heauens chearefull face did vew,
Yet since thou bidst, thy pleasure shalbe donne.
Since late she saw him fall before his enemy.
But since now safe ye seised haue the shore,
But since that band ye cannot now release,
Therefore since now to thee perteines the same,
Therefore since mine he is, or free or bond,
Since errant armes to sew he first began;
For since the Redcrosse knight he earst did weet,
Since he this hardie enterprize began:
Yet since no way is left to wreake my spight,
Since which, with sundrie spoiles she hath beene ransacked.
And preacht the truth, but since it greatly did decay.
Who after long debate, since Lucies time,
Happie this Realme, had it remained euer since.
But since thy faithfull zeale lets me not hyde
Fiue dayes there be, since he (they say) was slaine,
And foure, since Florimell the Court for-went,
Yet since he seemed valiant, through vnknowne,
Then since that strange Knights loue from him was quitted,
Since so good fortune doth to you present
Since therefore she her selfe is now your ward,
Then since (quoth she) the terme of each mans life
That since their days such louers were not found elswhere.
For since the day that they created beene,
Since with the rest she went not after Florimell.
The fayrest Ladie reft, and euer since withheld.
Long since in that enchaunted glasse she saw.
Since I was brought into this dolefull den;
Whom seeking euer since with endlesse paines,
For since the day that first with deadly wound
Since of my loue at length I rest assured,
But since ye so desire, your will be donne.
Or that in Cyprus, both long since this same,
Her to redresse: but since he meanes found none
Yet since she saw the streight extremitie,
For since the terme of fourteene hundred fyeres,
That since the time they first tooke the Sunnes hight,
Since he himselfe it vs'd in that great fight
But this same other Damzell since hath fained,
Yet loth she was, since she no ill did heare,
Since that he was not forst, nor ouercome in fight?
And dead long since in dolorous distresse,
Since neither is endamadg'd much thereby.
Who through his yeares long since aside had set
Sith which she hath me euer since abhord,
Gainst whom Sir Artegall, long hauing since
Since it at first was by the Gods with paine
Then since the saluage Island I did leaue
Yet since ye mercie now doe need to craue,
But since it me concernes, my selfe to clere,
Yet since he was not presently in plight
For since the day that armes I first did reare,
Since I was ten yeares old, now growen to stature strong.
The rather since that fortune hath this day
But since this Ladie is all desolate,
Since first he saw her, and did free from feare
Yet since it was his fortune, not his fault,
Since I him lately lost, vneath is to define.
In piteous languor, since ye hither came,
Yet since thy life vnto this Ladie fayre
That since by grace of God she there was sent,
Since then in each mans self (said Calidore)
But since things passed none may now restore,
Long since had fought in field. Als Claribell
Ne more sincere in word and deed profest;
The charme fulfild, dead suddenly he downe did sincke.
To sincke into his sence, nor mind affect,
And euery sinew seene through his long fast:
And all his sinews woxen weake and raw,
To sinfull house of Pride, Duessa
Puft vp with emptie wind, and fild with sinfull crime.
Or weaknesse is to sinfull bands made thrall:
Is not the measure of thy sinfull hire
So much the dart of sinfull guilt the soule dismayes.
Which sinfull horror workes in wounded hart,
And shewes the way, his sinfull soule to saue.
His chosen people purg'd from sinfull guilt,
And guilt of sinfull crimes cleane wash away,
In frayle intemperance through sinfull bayt;
To purge away the guilt of sinfull crime:
No wretchednesse is like to sinfull vellenage.
The lothfull life, now loosd from sinfull bands,
For she was pure from blame of sinfull blot,
His sinfull soule with desperate disdaine,
That thou hast shewed to me sinfull wight,
Hast drest my sinfull wounds? I kisse thy blessed feete.
Ordained hath, he clothes with sinfull mire,
Because his sinfull lust she would not serue,
That hast with shamefull spot of sinfull lust
But ere she could him reach, the sinfull sowle
That did resort of sinfull people shonne;
To sinfull men with darknes ouerdight,
Offring to him in sinfull sacrifice
And sing of Knights and Ladies gentle deeds;
And eke the Graces seemed all to sing,
For fairest Vnaes sake, of whom I sing,
And well could daunce, and sing with ruefulnesse,
Till I of warres and bloudy Mars do sing,
No bird, but did her shrill notes sweetly sing;
And all the quire of birds did sweetly sing,
Whilst round about them pleasauntly did sing
To sing his mistresse prayse, and let him mend,
And oft young birds, which he had taught to sing
To such therefore I do not sing at all,
To her I sing of loue, that loueth best,
The which did pype and sing her prayses dew,
Three other Ladies did both daunce and sing,
Shouting, and singing all a shepheards ryme,
Singing before th'eternall maiesty,
Now singing sweetly, to surprise her sprights,
And singing all her sorrow to the note,
And shepheards singing to their flockes, that fed,
Her single person to their barbarous truth,
That scarsely could he weeld his bootlesse single blade.
Encountring fierce with single sword in hand,
That rode in golden sell with single spere,
His single speare could doe him small redresse,
For thirst of single kingdome him he kild.
That of a single damzell thou wert met
Bad those same sixe forbeare that single enimy.
Whereto that single knight did answere frame;
To single combat with Sir Satyrane.
Druons delight was all in single life,
There she resolu'd her selfe in single fight
And with his single shield, well as he might,
Of fayre Irenaes cause with him in single fight.
Thereto he had great skill in single fight:
And passing well expert in single fight,
Now that he had her singled from the crew
Like as an Hynd forth singled from the heard,
Gainst whom there singled from the other side
Where singled forces faile, conioynd may gaine.
And all the way the ioyous people sings,
A song of bale and bitter sorrow sings,
Besides a thousand more of such, as sings
There an huge heape of singulfes did oppresse
As women wont, but with deepe sighes, and singulfs few.
She poured forth out of her hellish sinke
Thrise did she sinke adowne in deadly swownd,
Ne ought mote euer sinke downe to the bottome there.
And powred out of her infernall sinke
The filthy blots of sinne to wash away.
Gan dight him selfe vnto his wonted sinne;
Now when the world with sinne gan to abound,
Is not his law, Let euery sinner die:
And prickt with anguish of his sinnes so sore,
Else had his sinnes so great, and manifold
That for the sinnes of all the world was kilt:
Is sacrilege, and doth all sinnes exceed;
For all the sinnes, wherewith his lewd life did abound.
The Britons, for their sinnes dew punishment,
And dared of all sinnes the secrets to vnfold.
To wreake the guilt of mortall sins is bent,
Shall he thy sins vp in his knowledge fold,
Sir knight with-hold, till further triall made.
Cride out, Now now Sir knight, shew what ye bee,
Then with the Sunne take Sir, your timely rest,
Right well Sir knight ye haue aduised bin,
And said, Ah Sir, my liege Lord and my loue,
Cride, Mercy mercy Sir vouchsafe to show
Deare Sir, what euer that thou be in place:
And said; faire Sir, I hope good hap hath brought
Therefore, deare Sir, your mightie powres assay.
Henceforth sir knight, take to you wonted strength,
Sir Treuisan flies from Despayre,
Sir knight, aread who hath ye thus arayd,
For Gods deare loue, Sir knight, do me not stay;
Sir Terwin hight, that well himselfe aduaunst
Ne yet assur'd of life by you, Sir knight,
O neuer Sir desire to try his guilefull traine.
And you Sir knight, whose name mote I request,
Arise, Sir knight arise, and leaue this cursed place.
And you good Sir, I wote that of your toyle,
But if your selfe, Sir knight, ye faultie find,
The good Sir Guyon gratiously to heare,
And knighthood tooke of good Sir Huons hand,
That you, most noble Sir, had present beene,
And cryde, Mercie Sir knight, and mercie Lord,
Ah deare Sir Guyon, well becommeth you,
Sir Guyon, why with so fierce saliaunce,
But you, faire Sir, whose pageant next ensewes,
Whom when the good Sir Guyon did behold,
Gay steed with spurs did pricke, the good Sir Mortdant was.
Faire Sir, if euer there ye trauell, shonne
That seeing good Sir Guyon, could vneath
Sir Guyon more affection to increace,
Thus when Sir Guyon with his faithfull guide
Ne certes Sir striue you it to withstand,
Which when Sir Guyon saw, all were he wroth,
Was hight Sir Huddibras, an hardy man;
Tell on, faire Sir, said she, that dolefull tale,
Sir Guyon mindfull of his vow yplight,
Had slaine Sir Mordant, and his Lady bright:
Perdie Sir knight, said then th'enchaunter bliue,
All haile, Sir knight, and well may thee befall,
Therewith Sir Guyon left his first emprise,
Faire Sir (quoth he) what man can shun the hap,
He boldly spake, Sir knight, if knight thou bee,
It booted nought Sir Guyon comming neare
Eftsoones his cruell hand Sir Guyon stayd,
Sir Knight, that thus ye now subdewed arre:
Thereat Sir Guyon smilde, And is that all
Helpe, Ã´ Sir Guyon, helpe most noble knight,
Vnder Sir Guyons puissaunt stroke to fall,
Faire Sir (quoth she) be not displeasd at all;
And in the way he with Sir Guyon met,
Sir Guyon grudging not so much his might,
Him followed eke Sir Guyon euermore,
Sir Guyon laid in swowne is by
Certes, Sir knight, ye bene too much to blame,
Faire Sir, said then the Palmer suppliaunt,
But you, faire Sir, whose honorable sight
Sir Guyons sword he lightly to him raught,
So did Sir Guyon[Prince Arthur] beare himselfe in fight,
By this Sir Guyon from his traunce awakt,
And said, Deare sir, whom wandring to and fro
To whom the Infant thus, Faire Sir, what need
Sir knight, mote I of you this curt'sie read,
Faire Sir (said he) if in that picture dead
But you, faire Sir, be not herewith dismaid,
Gramercy Sir (said he) but mote I wote,
Then gan Sir Guyon all the story shew
Faire Sir, (said she halfe in disdainefull wise,)
Faire Sir at that, which ye so much embrace?
Sir Guyon chaunst eke on another booke,
Vprose Sir Guyon, in bright armour clad,
Therefore, Sir Palmer, keepe an euen hand;
Faire Sir, be not displeasd, if disobayd:
Therefore, Sir knight, your ready armes about you throw.
So did he eke Sir Guyon passing by:
When thus the Palmer; Now Sir, well auise;
Which seeing good Sir Guyon, deare besought
Therefore a read Sir, if thou haue a loue.
For thy, faire Sir, yours be the Damozell,
Faire Sir, I let you weete, that from the howre
And thus replide, How euer, Sir, ye file
And said, Sir knight, these idle termes forbeare,
Sir knight, that doest thy voyage rashly make
The Dwarfe him answerd, Sir, ill mote I stay
Which way she fared hath, good Sir tell out of hand.
But can ye read Sir, how I may her find, or where.
Therefore, faire Sir, for loue of knighthood gent,
Saue to the noble knight Sir Scudamore,
It was to weete the good Sir Satyrane,
By this the good Sir Satyrane gan wake
In deed Sir knight (said he) one word may tell
But if that thou, Sir Satyran, didst weete,
Or thou, Sir Peridure, her sorie state,
But if Sir Calidore could it presage,
Sir Satyrane him towards did addresse,
Ah gentle knight (said then Sir Satyrane)
Then said, Faire Sir, how may I weene it trew,
Faire Sir (quoth he) well may it you succeed,
Thereat Sir Satyrane gan smile, and say;
Sir Satyrane, that glaunces might not glyde:
Sir Paris far renowmd through noble fame,
The ruefull story of Sir Paridell,
Behold, Sir, how your pitifull complaint
Old Mnemon. Therefore Sir, I greet you well
Good Sir, let not my rudenesse be no breach
And eke Sir Paridell, all were he deare;
Soone as the old man saw Sir Paridell,
Who with Sir Satyrane, as earst ye red,
Ne was Sir Satyrane her far behinde,
Therefore, faire Sir, do comfort to you take,
And said; Sir knight, your cause is nothing lesse,
Inglorious and beastlike is: therefore Sir knight,
She left Sir Scudamour in great distresse,
Lo there Sir Paridel, for your desart,
But answerd, Sir him wise I neuer held,
Then that which he had to Sir Paridel resynd.
To be Sir Scudamour, by that he bore
Faire Sir, of friendship let me now you pray,
Ah Sir (said Paridel) do not dismay
Ne be ye wroth Sir Scudamour therefore,
So stood Sir Scudamour, when this he heard,
It was to weete the bold Sir Ferraugh hight,
That to Sir Paridell these words he sent;
Sir knight why ride ye dumpish thus behind,
And you Sir Blandamour and Paridell,
Thereat Sir Blandamour with countenance sterne,
Gainst whom Sir Priamond with equall worth:
Right practicke was Sir Priamond in fight,
Sir Triamond at last full faint and feeble stood.
Twixt Cambell and Sir Triamond befell,
Gainst whom Sir Paridell himselfe addrest,
And said, Sir Knight, sith ye this Lady clame,
Then first of all forth came Sir Satyrane,
Then tooke the bold Sir Satyrane in hand
And him against Sir Blandamour did ride
Which to auenge, Sir Deuon him did dight,
And after him Sir Douglas him addrest,
And after him Sir Paliumord forth prest,
And now by this, Sir Satyrane abraid,
But mongst them all, was not Sir Triamond,
It chaunst Sir Satyrane his steed at last,
That was to weet, the stout Sir Sangliere,
Sir Brianor, so sore, that none him life behote.
Thus was Sir Satyrane with all his band
Next did Sir Triamond vnto their sight
Then did Sir Ferramont vnto them shew
To single combat with Sir Satyrane.
And at them both Sir Paridell did loure.
Sir Scudamour there entring, much admired
There lay Sir Scudamour long while expecting,
But reade you Sir, sith ye my name haue hight,
Then this, Sir Saluage Knight (quoth he) areede;
Sayd then Sir Scudamour, Sir Saluage knight
Sayd then Sir Scudamour, Sir Saluage knight
But toward th'end Sir Arthegall renewed
He thus bespake; Certes Sir Artegall,
And you Sir Artegall, the saluage knight,
Her thus bespake; But Sir without offence
To whom thus Britomart, Certes Sir knight,
Till Glauce thus; Faire Sir, be nought dismayd
Great cause of sorrow certes Sir ye haue:
All being guided by Sir Artegall.
In all which time, Sir Artegall made way
Sir Artegall, who all this while was bound
Certes sir Knight[s], ye seemen much to blame,
Then good sir Claribell him thus bespake,
Now were it not sir Scudamour to you,
Sir Sanglier; (so cleeped was that Knight)
And you, Sir Knight, that loue so light esteeme,
Much did that Squire Sir Artegall adore,
Ne was Sir Artegall behinde: so both
Which oddes when as Sir Artegall espide,
Sir Artegall vndid the euill fashion,
And first of all issu'd Sir Marinell,
The first of them was hight Sir Orimont,
The second had to name Sir Bellisont,
Sir Artegall into the Tilt-yard came,
So backe he brought Sir Marinell againe;
Who came not forth, but for Sir Artegall
So stood Sir Marinell, when he had seene
Sir Guyon as by fortune then befell,
Thereby Sir Artegall did plaine areed,
Lo there Sir Guyon, take to you the steed,
Saying, Sir knight, it would dishonour bee
So did he mitigate Sir Artegall;
Then weete ye Sir, that we two brethren be,
Sir Terpine, haplesse man, what make you here?
But tell, Sir Terpin, ne let you amate
Therefore Sir Terpin from you lightly throw
Sir Terpin, from her direfull doome acquit,
Together with sir Terpin all that night:
So did Sir Artegall vpon her lay,
To her bespake; Sir Knight it seemes to me,
Meane while her noble Lord sir Artegall
Prince Arthure and Sir Artegall,
Sir Artegall, to whom she streight did hie
Sir Artegall, without discretion
Saying, Sir Knight, of pardon I you pray,
First, that sir Artegall should him array,
So as they had deuiz'd, sir Artegall
Where hauing with Sir Artegall a space
And to his Lord Sir Artegall it lent,
Then turning vnto him; And you Sir knight
And further sayd; Ah Sir, but mote ye please,
Then wote you, Sir, that in this Church hereby,
Haile good Sir Sergis, truest Knight aliue,
Did much abash Sir Artegall to heare,
But now aread, Sir Sergis, how long space,
Now turne againe (Sir Artegall then sayd)
Assure your selfe, Sir Knight, she shall haue ayd,
Of whom Sir Artegall gan then enquire
To whom Sir Burbon, blushing halfe for shame,
To whom thus Artegall; Certes Sir knight,
Sir Artegall, albe he earst did wyte
Artegall doth Sir Burbon aide,
Gainst whom Sir Artegall, long hauing since
The whyles Sir Artegall, with that old knight
That night Sir Artegall did cause his tent
Sir Artegall, in battailous array
And linckt together gainst Sir Artegall,
Sir Artegall return'd from his late quest,
If her Sir Artegall had not preserued,
To whom Sir Artegall gan to expresse
Now happy man (sayd then Sir Calidore)
What is that quest (quoth then Sir Artegall)
Now God you speed (quoth then Sir Artegall)
Sir Calidore thence trauelled not long,
Such was the fury of Sir Calidore,
Ne ought dismayed was Sir Calidore,
Cryde out, Ah mercie Sir, doe me not slay,
Sir Calidore vpcheard, and to her teld
And after all, vnto Sir Calidore
Perdie great blame, (then said Sir Calidore)
Much did Sir Calidore admyre his speach
Sayd then Sir Calidore; Neither will I
Certes Sir knight (sayd she) full loth I were
Now sure (then said Sir Calidore) and right
Sir knight, that by discouering my estate,
Therefore, good Sir, sith now occasion fit
All which when well Sir Calidore had heard,
Whereat Sir Calidore did much delight,
And turne we backe to good Sir Calidore;
Then gan Sir Calidore to ghesse streightway
That to Sir Calidore was easie geare;
Sir Calidore his faith thereto did plight,
To whom Sir Calidore approaching nye,
And now by this Sir Calepine, so hight,
Sir Calepine her thanckt, yet inly wroth
Is hight Sir Turpine, one of mickle might,
To whom she thus, What need me Sir to tell,
The wife of bold Sir Bruin, who is Lord
The good Sir Bruin, growing farre in yeares;
The good Sir Calepine, that farre was strayd,
Sir Calepine himselfe away had hidden it.
Wrought to Sir Calidore so foule despight;
Yet thus at length he said, How now Sir Knight?
They met Prince Arthure with Sir Enias,
And to the Prince thus sayd; See you Sir Knight,
Stay stay, Sir Knight, for loue of God abstaine,
Ah nay Sir Knight (sayd she) it may not be,
The good Sir Calepine, her owne true Knight,
Sir Calepine by chaunce, more then by choyce,
To whom Sir Calidore yet sweating comes,
Her whyles Sir Calidore there vewed well,
And thus bespake; Sir knight, your bounteous proffe[r]
So there that night Sir Calidore did dwell,
Right sory I, (saide then Sir Calidore,)
Sir Calidore him arm'd, as he thought best,
Sir Calidore when thus he now had raught
Whereof was Lord the good Sir Bellamoure;
Nathlesse Sir Bellamour, whether through grace
Tho gan Sir Calidore him to aduize
The good Sir Pelleas him tooke in hand,
And after him Sir Lamoracke of yore,
An aged Sire, in long blacke weedes yclad,
But hardly was restreined of that aged sire.
Of one bad sire, whose youngest is Sans ioy,
And bore a boy vnto that saluage sire:
That his owne sire and maister of his guise
To see his sire and offspring auncient.
And blustring AEolus his boasted sire,
And said, Old sire, it seemes thou hast not red
For both the lignage and the certain Sire,
There they do finde that godly aged Sire,
O holy Sire (quoth he) how shall I quight
That aged Sire, the Lord of all that land,
She to her Sire made humble reuerence,
He seemd to be a sage and sober sire,
The children of one sire by mothers three;
Ne gaue him leaue to bid that aged sire
Till that him thus bespake their soueraigne Lord & sire.
Behold this heauie sight, thou reuerend Sire,
And them beside an aged Sire did trace,
That sire he foule bespake, Thou dotard vile,
Crau'd leaue of Alma, and that aged sire,
Of whom it hight; but in the end their Sire
That she resolu'd, vnweeting to her Sire,
Vngratious children of one gracelesse sire,
Her sire Typhoeus was, who mad through merth,
An aged sire with head all frory hore,
My Sire, who me too dearely well did loue,
Both sire, and friends, and all for euer to forego.
Her owne deare sire, she cald to him for aide.
But grieued was for losse both of her sire,
Whom of their sire Nereides men call,
Of mortall sire, though of immortall wombe,
The which her sire had scrap't by hooke and crooke;
To whom our sire, Milesio by name,
Nor sire, nor sonnes, nor any could she spie:
And to their sire their carcasses left to bestow.
They doe thy sire, lamenting sore for thee;
Most ioyfull man her sire was her to see,
Aread good sire, some counsell, that may vs sustaine.
Of thy sires Crowne, and from thy countrey deare.
Proud Sisera, and how Camill' hath slaine
Her sonne Sisillus after her did rayne,
Her younger sister, that Speranza hight,
As was her sister; whether dread did dwell,
Then Vna thus; But she your sister deare;
Of second sister, who did far excell
For both did at their second sister grutch,
Binding her sister, she to him ran hastily.
And all her sister Nymphes with one consent
Sister of heauie death, and nourse of woe,
And his faire sister for creation
Faire sister, ill beseemes it to vpbrayd
Spare, gentle sister, with reproch my paine to eeke.
For as the sister did in feminine
Cambelloes sister was fayre Canacee,
And of them all the victour should his sister take.
And fifty sisters water in leake vessels draw.
By hearing her, and by her sisters lore,
Her sisters two Extremities:
Therein three sisters dwelt of sundry sort,
Newes hereof to her other sisters came,
